Description: Shoulder sherd of Clazomenian black-figured pottery neck-amphora; exterior: band of alternating red and black tongues with white dots in interstices above black-figure frieze: siren to left (head, wings and upper body remaining; white on flesh, chest and dots on wing, and red on hair, fillet and wing); at left, part of perhaps a second siren.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Edgar (in Hogarth 1898-99, 61) states that the sherd belongs to the same vase as GR.300b.1899 however the ear, hair and fillet on both sirens are significantly different from each other. Cook suggests that the decoration on the sherd is close in style to the decoration on vases from the Urla Group.
Bibliographic references: Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (p. 61, pl. VIII, no. 2a)
CVA Cambridge II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain, Fascicule 11, Cambridge, Fascicule 2 (p. 38, no. 7, pl. XIX, no. 7)
Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 139, no. 9)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 254, no. 9)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GH.123) (phase 3)
